> 1. Is it considered bad taste to use parameters (i.e. ?id=3D1) within
the=

> URL? From what I have read it is but everyone seems to be doing it.

Thi=
s is an excellent question, and has also been a question on my mind
of late=
.
 
My thinking is this: The sole purpose of a URL is to "identify" a
resou=
rce.  
 
Tim Berners-Lee Axiom 0: every resource on the Web shall be unique=
ly
identified by a URL.
 
For example, this (logical URL) identifies a 747 =
aircraft resource:
 
http://www.boeing.com/aircraft/747
 
If we agree that =
the sole purpose of a URL is to identify a resource,
then I cannot see why =
a person would ever use query strings.  If
information needs to be passed t=
o the resource, then you must ask
"why?"  Are you wishing to update a resou=
rce?  If so, then you should
POST the information to the resource (and the =
resource is identified
using a logical URL without any query strings).
 
I =
am eager to hear what others are thinking on this topic.  /Roger
